'Twas morning and Mary arose,</br>Her stockings and garters put on;</br>Instinctively follow'd her nose,</br>And walk'd with her back to the Sun.
She smil'd and the woods were illum'd,</br>She sigh'd and the vales were depress'd;</br>She breath'd and the air was perfum'd,</br>She frown'd and saw nature distress'd.
She nodded — the tree nodded too,</br>She murmur'd, and so did the rill,</br>She wept, and the evening dew—</br>Fell in tears on the neighbouring hill.
She stept and fair flow'rs sprang up,</br>She blush'd and the rose look'd more red,</br>She was hungry — she went home and supt,</br>She was tired, and so — went to bed.</br>
